title: Strong UK housing market delivers record year for Galliford Try
text:

Wed, Sep 16, 2015, 09:40 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 50 mins Strong UK housing market delivers record year for Galliford Try By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 9 minutes ago 1,773.00 -28.0000 
Revenues and profits have jumped at the FTSE-250 housebuilder as demand for new homes continues to rise 
Galliford Try (LSE: GFRD.L - news ) is the latest British housebuilder to report record results, posting revenues of £2.4bn for the year to June 30, up 30pc on 2014. 
Pre-tax profits at the the FTSE-250 housebuilder rose 20pc over the year to hit £114m. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) completed on 3,177 homes, up from 3,107 last year and the average sale price of property in its Linden Homes division rose 7pc to £327,000. 
Executive chairman Greg Fitzgerald said that the business had been "buoyed by encouraging market trends ". 
The company, which also works on infrastructure projects, has benefitted from increased demand for property in the UK and the ongoing shortage of housing stock . 
Housebuilders Barratt Developments , Taylor Wimpey , and Bovis Homes have all recently reported strong growth in revenues and earnings. 
A rise in singletons buying property, and a continuing need for affordable housing, have also boosted Gallford. 
Unlike its rivals, the company made no mention of the Government's Help To Buy scheme in its results, which has been credited for driving the housing boom. 
In February this year, Galliford Try posted a record set of half-year results, breaking the £1bn revenue barrier for the first time. 
Galliford Try intends to boost its final dividend to 46p per share, an increase of 21pc. 
Building costs are rising, however, Mr Fitzerald warned: "All businesses saw high levels of build cost inflation but early signs indicate the situation may be moderating." 
In May this year, Galliford acquired Yorshire-based Shepherd Homes, which the company said has helped to stamp its brand on the North. 
The company now has a total landbank of 15,750 plots, up from 14,000 plots last year. However net debt rose from £5.1m to £17.3m as it borrowed to fund its expansion. 
Its infrastructure construction business also doubled the size of its order book in July last year when it bought Miller Construction for £16.6m. 
Mr Fitzgerald is due to retire from the business later this year, after serving 33 years at the helm.
